title: 107_s1134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Venture Capital Gains and Growth Act of 2001" and includes modifications applicable to qualified small business stock. The "Venture Capital Gains and Growth Act of 2001" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, such as the repeal of minimum tax preference and an increase in the rollover period for qualified small business stock from 60 days to 180 days. The "Venture Capital Gains and Growth Act of 2001" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by extending the rollover period for qualified small business stock from 60 days to 180 days. Additionally, the holding period for partial exclusion for gains from certain small business stock is reduced from 5 years to 3 years. The "Venture Capital Gains and Growth Act of 2001" extends the rollover period for qualified small business stock to 180 days. The holding period for partial exclusion for gains from certain small business stock is reduced from 5 years to 3 years. Per-issuer limitations on taxpayer's eligible gain are repealed, and the definition of qualified trade or business is amended. The "Venture Capital Gains and Growth Act of 2001" extends the rollover period for qualified small business stock to 180 days and reduces the holding period for partial exclusion for gains from certain small business stock to 3 years. Per-issuer limitations on taxpayer's eligible gain are repealed, and the definition of qualified trade or business is amended to include anticipation of continued reputation. Working capital limitation under Section 1202(e)(6) is modified to extend the period to 5 years and remove the last sentence. The working capital limitation under Section 1202(e)(6) is amended to extend the period to 5 years and remove the last sentence. Additionally, an exception from redemption rules is added for purchases of stock by the issuing corporation with a business purpose. The purchase of stock by the issuing corporation may be disregarded if a business purpose is established and avoiding limitations is not a principal purpose. This amendment increases the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock under Section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment increases the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock under Section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 from 50 percent to 100 percent. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The Code is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from small business stock under Section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code from 50% to 100%. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code. Section 1(h) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to redesignate certain paragraphs, the heading for section 1202 is updated, and the table of sections is modified to reflect a 100% exclusion for gain from small business stock. The table of sections for part I of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to change "Partial" to "100-percent" in the item for section 1202. Amendments are made to section 1202 to allow for a full exclusion for gains from certain small business stock for corporations. Amendments to section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code allow for a full exclusion for gains from certain small business stock. Stock held among members of a parent-subsidiary controlled group is not eligible for the exclusion. Amendments to section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code increase the asset limitation for qualified small businesses from $50,000,000 to $300,000,000. Additionally, stock held by a group member is not eligible for the exclusion. The asset limitation for qualified small businesses under section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code is increased to $300,000,000 with an inflation adjustment provision. The amendments made by this section increase the asset limitation for qualified small businesses to $300,000,000 with an inflation adjustment provision. The effective date applies to stock issued after the enactment of this Act.
